In many developed countries, there is a ritual called municipal refuse collection where rubbish bags are collected regularly and taken to a local tip. This ceremony is peculiar because in most places, it is free. However, the cost of rubbish disposal is not zero. If rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. To reduce the amount of rubbish, people could be charged for disposing of their waste. This would give them an incentive to throw out less and recycle more.
But the effects of seemingly simple policies are often complex. Intricate economic models are often needed to sort them out. And sometimes, the results of this rummaging do not smell sweet.

Work can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience, but it can also be stressful and unsatisfying. To be successful in your career, you need to be able to communicate effectively, be creative, and be able to work well with others. If you are not able to do these things, you will not be able to enjoy your work, even if you have a high-paying job.
In order to be successful in your work, you need to be able to communicate effectively. This means being able to listen to others, speak clearly, and write well. You also need to be able to build strong relationships with your colleagues and clients.
If you are able to communicate effectively, be creative, and work well with others, you will be able to find a job that is both rewarding and fulfilling.

Broadcasting is a technology that is used to spread seeds broadly. It is also a metaphor for optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth and the production of a rich harvest.
The metaphor of broadcasting as sowing seeds is a good one because it is related to the way that television is used. Television is a two-way form of communication that is used to transmit words and pictures. It is also a centralised medium, which means that it is controlled by a single source.
In the early days of television, there were a lot of experiments with different ways to organise the technology. However, the most successful organisation was the one that was based on centralised broadcasting to a dispersed domestic audience. This is because it was the most practical way to use the technology.
As a result of the widespread use of broadcasting technology, people were able to achieve improved standards of living and enter 'consumer' society. They were also able to experience a wide range of cultural experiences.
The pervasiveness of these structured processes and interests rendered broadcasting the 'naturally' victorious organisation of both radio and television.

However, theatre audiences are still generous and demanding. They are willing to follow artists into the most unpromising spaces.

In those days, the council houses in West Earlham were like row after row of huddled, dingy dwellings. The chemicals from the factory came and hung around the doors and gardens with a strong smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked on someone's front path. Most of my early life I've forgotten, but I have a memory of sitting on a vantage point near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they faded away into the distance. Later on, there are other memories that I can't put names to. My mother was a small, precise and nearly always angry woman. She was very lonely and had a strange way of behaving. Sometimes she would get angry and clean the house or wash her hands. Sometimes she would be very quiet and listen to the radio. I remember my mother taking me to the Norwich Castle Museum on Sundays. Here, hand-in-hand, we would parade through roomfuls of paintings. My mother wasn't altogether averse to this recreation, and eventually almost got to have opinions on the various subjects presented for her edification.

Charles Darwin thought that humans have a natural tendency to cry. It is not clear why we cry, but there are a few possible reasons. One reason is that crying can help us to connect with others. When we see someone else crying, we often feel sympathy and want to help them. Another reason is that crying can help us to express our emotions. When we are sad, we often cry to let others know that we are unhappy. Finally, crying can also be a reflex response to certain stimuli, such as hearing music or watching a movie.

The Earth is getting warmer, and this is causing a lot of changes to the planet. The changes are affecting plants, animals, water, and soils. They are also having a big impact on human societies.
One of the biggest problems is that we do not know exactly how much the world will change. We also do not know what is causing the changes. However, we do know that human activity is a major factor in the changes.
Scientists are working to predict the future effects of climate change. They use computer programs called general circulation models, or GCMs, to do this. GCMs are not perfect, but they can give us some idea of what might happen.
The effects of climate change are already being felt around the world. For example, the average global surface temperature has increased by about 6C over the past century. The average sea level is also rising. And the patterns of precipitation are changing.
Climate change is a serious problem, but it is also an opportunity. Some climate change impacts will probably be beneficial. For example, the average yield of wheat has increased in Australia. However, many of the predicted effects of future climate warming are far from beneficial. These effects include increased flooding, droughts, and changes to glacial processes.
The rise in sea levels is one of the most dramatic and visible effects of climate change. It is caused by the thermal expansion of the ocean and the added input from melting ice. With scientists calculating that about half of the world's population live in coastal zones, the consequences of rising sea levels are potentially very severe.

They will lead to valuable advances for future missions.

Art is a special form of experience that involves refined and intensified forms of enjoyment. However, the existence of art products can sometimes make it difficult to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art products are often seen as separate from human experience. When art products are isolated from their original conditions and experiences, they become difficult to understand. In order to understand art, we need to forget it for a time and turn aside from it. We need to have recourse to the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. Once we have done this, we can begin to understand the aesthetic in its ultimate and approved forms.

The early years of the 1990s were tough for advertising professionals. There was a recession in business that was longer, deeper and more severe than anyone could have predicted. It affected every single business in the country, including advertising agencies. Many people lost their jobs and homes, and businesses found themselves struggling.
Despite the challenges, advertising professionals still feel pressure to do their jobs well. They are often asked to do more with less, and they have to deal with the fact that their work is being constantly scrutinized.
However, there has also been a positive side to the recession. It has made companies realize that they need to focus more on their customers and produce advertising that is relevant to their needs. This has led to a rise in the perceived importance of marketing professionals.
Overall, the early years of the 1990s were a difficult time for advertising professionals. However, there have also been some positive changes that have made the job more challenging and rewarding.

When I was at university, I decided to become a chef. It was an unusual choice, but I was unhappy at university and I wanted to do something that I loved. Cooking was my passion. I started to learn how to cook by reading cookbooks, roaming markets and delicatessens and preparing extravagant meals.
One day, I was eating at a famous restaurant in London. It was a revelation. I finished that meal wanting to prostrate myself weeping, at the feet of the chef who had made it. I felt warm and airy for days afterwards. After that, I developed an intense desire to uncover the secrets of this strange, fabulous art. I transformed my student life into an extended preparation for my assault on the culinary world.
I also learned to swim. I had a swimming instructor who was very strict. He taught me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head and roll forwards, pushing myself off with my feet. I practised that manoeuvre until the hour was up. The next visit, he got me standing upright, and diving off the edge. It was a lot of fun.

Summer promises us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. Books can help us to feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands. In the books of others, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling, or can express our very own thoughts, but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.
Reading and travel can help us to escape the deadening effect of habit. When we read a great book, our eyes are never more open than during our first few days in a new place. Our mind is like a radar newly attuned to pick up certain objects floating through consciousness. Through reading and travel, we find new things to appreciate and enjoy.

Music has become an integral part of our lives in the 21st century. In Britain, there has been a significant increase in the availability of music through various technologies such as radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, videos and the internet. However, this increased access has come at the expense of a decline in live music performance and employment opportunities for professional musicians. Despite these challenges, music continues to fulfill numerous human needs and is an integral part of many national and individual events.
In addition to its recreational benefits, playing an instrument can also have a positive impact on cognitive skills and social relationships. Research has shown that listening to or actively making music can improve spatial reasoning, concentration and social skills. These findings suggest that music education can be beneficial for people of all ages and abilities.
To ensure the continued growth and accessibility of music education, there are a few key areas that need to be addressed. These include the need to provide more opportunities for people to learn to play a range of instruments, adapt the instrumental curriculum and measures used to assess progress to be more inclusive of a broader population, and train musicians to be more effective motivators, educators and community leaders. By working together, the music profession can play a pivotal role in raising the profile of music and ensuring that its benefits are accessible to all.

Tiredness is a common problem in many countries. In the USA, 40 million people are affected by chronic tiredness. In Britain, some best-selling novels have featured insomniacs as protagonists. People often cut back on sleep when they are busy. They get up too early to avoid the rush hour.
There are some things that scientists know about human sleep. Humans sleep according to a daily cycle. They switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. When dreams occur, the brain paralyses the body except for the hands and eyelids.
However, there are also a lot of things that scientists don't know about human sleep. It is known that women sleep for half an hour longer than men, and that older people require less sleep. But beyond this, certainties blur into theories. It is often suggested that sleep repairs body tissue, or restores muscles, or rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity. But all of this may happen more quickly during relaxed wakefulness, so no one is really sure.

Photography has been used to record human life and activity for over a century. It has allowed us to see the fleeting moment and visualize both the vast and the minuscule. Photography has brought us images from remote areas of the world, distant parts of the solar system, and the social complexities and crises of modern life. It has also provided one of the most important and influential means of expressing the human condition.
The earliest creations of pictorial recording go back as far as the Upper Palaeolithic period of about 35,000 years ago. Pictures seem to be inextricably linked to human culture. Throughout the history of visual representation, questions have been raised about the accuracy and status of the visual image.
Photography has changed radically since its invention in 1839. It has moved into what might be termed 'mythic time' and has passed out of living memory. The passage of time has transformed the photograph from a memory aid into an historical document.

I have never started a novel with more worry. If I call it a novel, it is because I don't know what else to call it. I have a story to tell, but I don't end it with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader in the air. This book is about my memories of a man I knew. I have little knowledge of what happened to him between the times I saw him. I could fill in the gaps, but I don't want to do that. I only want to set down what I know. To save embarrassment to people still living, I have changed the names of the people in the story. I have also made sure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. It may be that he never will be. It may be that when his life at last comes to an end, he will leave no more trace of his sojourn on earth than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the surface of the water. Then my book, if it is read at all, will be read only for what intrinsic interest it may possess. But it may be that the way of life that he has chosen for himself and the peculiar strength and sweetness of his character may have an ever-growing influence over his fellow men so that, long after his death perhaps, it may be realised that there lived in this age a very remarkable creature. Then it will be quite clear of whom I write in this book and those who want to know at least a little about his early life may find in it something to their purpose. I think my book, within its acknowledged limitations, will be a useful source of information to my friend's biographers.

The other way is called the whole animal approach, which studies the behaviour of the intact animal. Within the whole animal approach, there are two main types of researchers. Psychologists study learning abilities in a restricted range of species. Ethologists study naturally occurring, unlearnt behaviour of animals. Although there is some overlap between the two types, they are different.

The Romans believed that architecture consisted of order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. Chen was amused by what his wife had been doing behind his back. He was happy that Lily had learned to drive. They made plans to go on a journey together.
They decided to leave early in the morning and return by midday. They drove to the English Channel. Lily had driven impeccably. Even Mui, sitting in the back, had to admit that Lily had done a good job. They parked in a small street off the sea front. Lily was worried about the road markings. She preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed away.
The journey was over the horizon and the ship was gone. Lily was left with a view of seagulls scavenging gash in the wake.

I was scared and worried about what would happen next. You called down and asked if I was all right. I was lying on the ground. You called again and asked me to let you help. I refused. I waited a while and then I climbed out of the well. I ran away from the well. I hid in the shadows. My mother and father came to see me. They were worried about me. They called me and asked me to tell them what happened. I told them my story. They didn't believe me. I was sad and disappointed. I felt like I had done something wrong. I was punished by my father. I was punished by my own shame.

Susan is a widow who lives in a lovely house. Her children are grown up and have moved away. The house is being removed. Everything that makes the house special is being packed away. The removers are taking the furniture away very carefully. They are handling the breakables with great care. The piano is the most important piece of furniture in the house. It is very valuable. The removers are struggling to get the piano up the stairs. It is difficult to move a heavy piano. Finally, the piano is moved into the new house. The children are happy that the piano is safe. They are laughing and playing. Susan is also happy. She is glad that the piano is safe.

The internet opened up new possibilities for literary criticism. One of the most significant benefits was the ability for anyone to share their opinions about books on Amazon.com. Anyone could write a review and post it on the site. This made it easy for people to see what others thought of a book. However, there were some challenges. For example, there was a lot of fake reviews and some people wrote reviews that were not very helpful. Despite these challenges, the democratisation of literary criticism has been a positive thing. It has made it easier for people to find books that they will enjoy.

Art has changed a lot in the last two hundred years. Today, we often praise artists for being unique and revolutionary. But sometimes we also criticize them for going too far. We expect artists to be different from the rest of us. We want them to have special talents and drive.
In the past, artists were often commissioned to create art for specific purposes. Today, we leave artists to their own devices. We get cross if they want to come down out of the clouds.
There is a new trend in art today. Artists are choosing to paint pictures of the world of the London Underground. This is a popular trend because it is unique and different.
I am a painter. I have escaped to this island with a few books. I am quite alone. I lie suspended like a hair or a feather in the cloudy mixtures of memory. I speak of the uselessness of art but add nothing truthful about its consolations. The solace of such work as I do with brain and heart lies in this - that only there, in the silences of the painter or the writer can reality be reordered, reworked and made to show its significant side.

My father collected me and my trunk from my posh school and sat through Parent's Day. He had a long conversation with my headteacher and was on his way to take me home and holidays. He said that I could do whatever I wanted now that I had all those certificates. He also said that he had heard that I would get a scholarship to Oxford University.
I was not sure what to say at first, but I agreed to do the assignment. My father was happy and said that he would see that it was more than worth my while. I felt like I was being controlled, but I knew that I had to do it.
In the end, I did the assignment and my father was pleased. He said that I was a good son and that he was proud of me.

Simon Costello knew that the purchase of the house in Pembroke Square had been a mistake. It was a possession that was only affordable by exercising stringent and calculated economy. At the time, it had seemed like a sensible and desirable move. But it had turned out to be a bad decision. The flat wasn't really suitable for a family, and they needed more room. All these things could have been achieved in a suburb or in a less fashionable part of London, but Lois was ambitious for more than additional space. She had decided that a necessary economy was for one of them to travel by public transport. Her firm was on the other side of London; obviously Simon must be the one to economise. The overcrowded tube journey was a mood of envious resentment and brooding. He remembered his grandfather's house in Hampstead and the smell of dinner from the kitchen. He remembered his grandmother's insistence that the returning breadwinner should be given peace and cosseting. The job was important to Lois and important to them both. The house, the au pair, their whole standard of living depended on two salaries. And now what they were precariously achieving could be destroyed by that self-righteous, interfering Venetia.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would find anonymity. But it was not to be. People in the shops started to recognize me. The roses in the garden were once loved, but they are gone now. I usually stay inside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying. I have cut back rosemary and lemon balm to make a space for a chair. It is a narrow London garden. My upstairs neighbour, Jaz, is leaning out of the window. She is writing a manuscript. I have a copy of the latest in my possession now. We talk for a while. I give her some advice about her writing. She is a bit upset, but I try to make her feel better. When I go inside, I feel calm. But then, out of the blue, I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine. She was about my age when I had her. She told us about her moments. We nearly died.

Heritage gives people and communities a sense of connection to the past. It is important for understanding and interpreting our individual and national futures. Heritage represents a desire for continuity. It affects everything from customs to material culture.
There are aspects of your national heritage that you may not like or condone, but it is yours, and it is reassuring to feel a part of something.
Museums exist to facilitate an encounter with authenticity. They present items that actually existed - were used - had meaning - at some historical time.
Architecture and Environment
The desire to preserve things is not new. Change in our towns comes with such speed and on such a scale that most of us are affected by it in some way. If there is a psychological need for preservation it is part of the planners job to take account of it.

Albert Einstein was a famous scientist who developed some important theories about time, space, and matter. His theories are called relativity and are very difficult to understand. Einstein made a big contribution to science by looking at the nature of the fundamentals of time, space, matter, and energy.
Previously, people thought that time and space were absolute. Einstein disagreed with this idea and said that time and space are relative. This means that they change depending on your point of view.
Young readers, Lydia and the author, used to distrust prize-winning books because they thought they would be boring. However, their father would give them money to read books and expose them to some good fiction and poetry.
Language is a fascinating subject. It is difficult to understand the origin and evolution of language. However, there are some interesting facts about language that can be learned.

Writing reviews is a skilled and multi-faceted job. It is one thing to write a short review for a newspaper, and quite another to write a long review for an international journal or a magazine. The reviewer needs to think about the probable audience, the length of the review, and the need to be able to write clearly and concisely. The reviewer also needs to know quite a bit about the book or article they are reviewing. If a reviewer is able to do all of these things well, they can write a review that is both informative and entertaining.

Ralph unlocked his flat door and entered the dark hall. He felt a sense of ownership when he returned home alone at the end of the day. His flat was like a space where he could focus and be himself. Sometimes, he would feel lonely and isolated, but he would also find comfort in his possessions and the quietness of his home.
Ralph often looked forward to his solitary evenings at home. He would read or listen to music as the night deepened outside. He would feel grateful that he had a place where he could be himself. But he would also feel lonely and powerless. Sometimes, he would feel like he was being swept away by the tide. He would feel like he was not in control of his own life.
Ralph had tried to improve himself after he left university, but he had not been successful. He had applied for jobs that were familiar to him, and he had latched himself on to the futures of his peers. He had attended his only interview and had been offered the job. He was grateful to have a place where he could be himself.

I was going to witness goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There was a lot of people and things around me, but I managed to get a good spot. The racecourse was not very big, but it was similar to other racecourses. The goats were being kept in order. It was difficult to keep the goats in order because they could eat almost anything. As the day was ending, I started to think about the night ahead. There was no place to sleep and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since early morning. We couldn't see what was happening, but we could hear the roaring noise of fast-rushing water. We moved on.

There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed very quickly, while others take much longer. Some can be speeded up, but others cannot. If you try to rush a task, it will probably break down.
There are also different ways to think. Some people think quickly and make decisions right away. Others think more slowly and carefully. There is a type of thinking that is called 'intellect'. It involves figuring out problems and making decisions. Another type of thinking is called 'creativity'. It involves coming up with new ideas and solutions.
The mind can also be used in a more relaxed way. This is called 'contemplation'. It is like thinking slowly and quietly. You can contemplate on a beach, or in bed, or even while you are walking. Contemplation can be very helpful for solving problems and coming up with new ideas.

I have been welcomed warmly to this foreign land. It's a friendly and well-equipped place where there are a lot of people. There are about forty people living here, mostly scientists, students, and weathermen. They all work together and help each other. My school French is good enough to communicate, but not to chat or have fun. I miss the subtleties and my phrasebook is not helpful at breakfast. There is no problem for me here, but there was a problem at first. I was worried about my self-confidence and I would hang back at mealtimes. But I'm still smiling and I sometimes panic when people talk to me. I think the reason for this is because I've lost the ability to talk to people easily.
When I first met Elliot, I was young and he didn't notice me. But he remembered my face and when I saw him again, he shook hands with me. We didn't talk much, but I became aware that he had a new feeling towards me. One day, I received a note from him asking me to lunch and I thought he was trying to test me out. But from then on, since I had become successful, I started to see him more often.
Alfred Hitchcock was a film director who believed that the most important thing about his films was the photography and the soundtrack. He didn't care about the subject matter or the acting. He thought that people are aroused by pure film, irrespective of their cultural background. Therefore, if a picture is designed correctly, the audience should react the same way, regardless of their nationality. Hitchcock's self-appraisal was always precise and rational. He was a man of reason and a craftsman of genius who liked to hear an audience scream.

Amateur Astronomy
Many things have changed in astronomy over the past few decades. In the past, there were not many charts and catalogues, and telescopic equipment was limited. Today, there is a wide range of telescopes and equipment available. Computers have made it easier to produce charts and analyze observations. All this makes it a good time for amateur astronomy.
However, there has also been a loss of things. Now, you may have to travel a long way to find a sky that is comparable to the sky found in urban areas 50 years ago. The daytime skies are now plagued by aircraft condensation trails which can last for hours and often spread out to form amorphous clouds, making solar observations impossible and hampering night-time observation too.
Society is also becoming more complex. There are too many things to do, too many options, and too many opportunities. This can be stressful and can make it difficult to focus on the simple things in life. As a result, there is a new trend emerging: the search for 'simplexity'.
McAndrews Hotel
Every summer, we spend a fortnight in McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition that has been going on for many years. Nothing is allowed to interfere with the ritual. We are of a kind, McAndrews clientele: old-fashioned, odd perhaps, some would say snobbish. I do not like the bad manners, the insolence of shop assistants which passes for egalitarianism in this present age; I resent chummy overtures from waiters who sometimes appear to restrain themselves with difficulty from slapping one on the back. I know most of my fellow-guests' names - like me they have been coming here since they were children - yet can rest assured that when I meet any of them in any part of the hotel, I shall be spared all social intercourse apart from a civil word of greeting. Such respect for dignity and personal privacy is hard to come by in commercial establishments these days.

Othello, a play by Shakespeare, was recently transferred to London from Stratford. The production is exceptional and allows me to make amends for an unfair review I wrote last spring. I complained that the actor Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role, but I think it's a distortion of the tragedy to remove the age difference between Othello and Desdemona. However, I appreciate Mr Fearon's magnificent performance. The whole cast is magnificent, and there are many memorable scenes in the play. The pace and tension throughout the play are terrific. Do not miss this production.
Lake Vostok is a hidden freshwater lake in Antarctica. It is covered by a thick layer of ice and has been isolated from air and sunlight for millions of years. Scientists are excited to explore Lake Vostok and discover what strange organisms live there.
Scientists were talking on the radio about why they become scientists. They said that it is because of their desire to understand everything from the atom to the black hole. But they also said that it is more important to know whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than get bogged down in debates over the point of it all.

There is a special connection between people and food. Cooking is a satisfying and rewarding experience that can bring joy to both adults and children. It is also a way to share your creativity and love with others. When you cook, you are offering a gift to your family and friends. Sharing food is a powerful symbol of human connection and celebration.
This morning, Alistair had a lot of paperwork to deal with. He had a lot of tax forms and other paperwork to file. He also had a lot of books and journals to organize. As he rode the elevator, he knew that his wife would be on time for their appointment. She is very organized and precise about time.
Karen had a desire not to be like her mother. She created her own story and mythology. In her story, there were significant moments in her progress. One day, she was hit in the eye by a golf club. But she was saved by the bone in her eye. She knew that she was saved for some purpose.
Miss Fogerty was excited and saddened by the scene she had just witnessed. She was excited to be the first to know something of note, but she was also saddened by Dr. Bailey's condition. Dr. Bailey has been a valuable doctor to the village for many years. He is known for his patience, knowledge, and humor.

Joanna MacGregor is a concert pianist who has a busy schedule. She has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano. Even though she is very busy, she still finds time to help children learn the piano.
One day, Joanna gave a concert for kids. There was a young boy who was not impressed by her performance. He asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna was surprised, but she agreed to play. She played the song and the boy was very happy.
Joanna is passionate about helping children learn the piano. She has written her own elementary piano tutor for children. She also runs her own recording label and has collaborated with many artists.
Joanna believes that everyone should be able to learn the piano. She says that learning should be unadulterated fun. She also believes that practice is the most important factor.

Writing and Reading
Dr Johnson said that writing without effort is generally read without pleasure. Good writing comes hard. Looking back at my handwritten school essays, I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. The slowness of the hand disciplined the brain. What would be difficult to alter or erase was written with care.
Books versus Electronic Text
Reading anything lengthy on a screen is such a miserable experience that most never do it. The organisation of what resides in computers encourages people to dip into text. What is new is not so much the branchings of electronic text as that computers don't invite the joined-up thinking of reading anything in its entirety.
Office Scene
Charles walked through the office door and into a perfect world of order. The carpet was clear of the paper avalanche which had buried it on the very day it was put down. The naked desk was dark wood, just as he remembered it from the Sotheby's auction of five weeks ago. He was admiring the room, its antique furniture. He was not visualising a computer or any other mechanical device in it, not even a pencil sharpener.

You don't take sugar, do you? The secretary shouted this as a fact. She had been making coffee for many months. She forgot to give him sugar because she thought he wasn't supposed to be there. But nowadays he was usually there all the time. He had discovered that if he didn't take up his privilege of staying away, he would have to open the floodgates. The secretary gave him a folder with a book label. The book label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." She also gave him a synopsis of the book. Lancelot did not want to see the synopsis. He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not really want to see another. The book was not finished yet. It was like a general with a million tons of equipment pinned down on the beach by nothing except an excess of opportunity. The book used up the budget for a dozen issues without appearing once.

In England, breakfast is an important meal according to health experts. It is not a very old meal in England. There are some references to people having breakfast in the Middle Ages, but most people did not have breakfast unless they were royalty or wealthy. However, in the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. This is because there was more food available and people often started working very early. As a result, people needed to have breakfast in order to be able to work.

When a photographer takes a photograph, they choose visual information based on their technical skills, aesthetics, personal views and experience, and cultural norms. These factors affect the style, content and expression of a photograph. They also influence how people perceive and respond to the images.
For example, a casual reader of a newspaper might understand the photographic images reproduced on the page. But they might also question whether the photograph accurately recorded the scene or if it communicates the photographer's point of view.
Sport has been more than just a game for me. It has taught me personal discipline, determination, and teamwork. It has also given me a great deal of satisfaction and opened doors for me.
Some experiences are so memorable that they leave a lasting impression on our memory. For me, such an experience took place one night in California when I heard the beautiful singing of a mockingbird. The bird's music was so captivating that it kept me awake all night.

Love them, fear them, worship them, human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. Birds have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people used to read the directions in which wrens flew to determine their luck. Today, the image of the wren is still in pictures and ceramics in many British households.
Birds are also important to us because they are indicators of environmental change. Conservationists in Britain cite the endangering of 30 species, which is a big loss of cultural heritage.
Folklore is important because it can help us to understand and appreciate birds. Stories, legends and rhymes about birds can evoke feelings and attitudes that we have forgotten. They also help us to connect with the past and to imagine the future.

A map is used to show the relationships between points and features on the Earth's surface. It is determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements did not give much information about the actual distance. Direction is also an important element of a map, but for ordinary travellers, it was not the most important thing. Written itineraries used to be popular for a long time, but maps are still used today. Certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, do not always show true directions. Landmarks along a route were sometimes indicated by signs. The history of cartography is the history of the increase in accuracy and comprehensiveness of maps. Cartography has called in other sciences to its aid, such as terrestrial magnetism and astronomy. The development of new technologies has also improved the accuracy and comprehensiveness of maps. Maps are a valuable record for the students of man's past.

I was invited to a young man's drawing room, which was like an oasis of culture. There was a lot of stuff in the room, but it was not very well organized. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour was like moving from economy to business class. I saw a lot of records and a stereo player. The young man's name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Oxford to read history. He had a lot of time to kill before he went up, so he was planning to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. I also had my own dreams, which were just as crazy as his. I wanted to be a pop star. I knew that my dreams were not life or death to me, but I still wanted to try to achieve them. When Andrew suggested a new ambition for me, I was willing to give it a go. He was a good musician and I could tell that he was going to be successful. We wrote some music together and parted ways. I was still interested in the charts than in the West End theatre, but I knew that I had just met somebody of rare ability and determination. I would continue to keep an eye out for opportunities to write music and would turn out a few more songs.

Language is a powerful tool that humans use to communicate and express themselves. It is an instinctive ability that we all have. When there is no one to talk to, people often talk to themselves or their pets. Climate and weather are two important factors that affect the lives of animals and plants. They can create landscapes and influence the distribution of living things. The air around us constantly moves and mixes, causing turbulence. The sun is a major source of turbulence. Coffee is a popular drink that people often order in restaurants. Making a good cup of coffee is an art and a science. It requires time and practice to learn the necessary skills.

Art on TV is not very successful at showing paintings and sculptures. It could be because the camera is not able to show the details of the artwork. There are few series on television that have managed to convey both the pleasure and complexity of looking at paintings and sculptures.
A good example of what goes wrong can be seen in Robert Hughes's eight-part survey of American art, American Visions. Hughes is a critic you can trust. He has a personality that commands attention and he has been given nearly eight hours in which to introduce British audiences to a school of art that British galleries have totally ignored. I had expected the series to focus on great works of art. What I got instead was one about the way American history and culture are reflected in its art and architecture.
Dealing in Metals is a risky business. But it can also be very profitable. With a bit of luck, a willingness to take a risk and a good understanding of how the market works, it's possible to make a lot of money.
Abaco and its off-shore cays are part of the Bahamas islands. They are a beautiful place to visit. You can get around Abaco by boat. There are plenty of ferries and water-taxis. Sailing is the most popular way to travel in Abaco. It's also a great place for fishing, diving, snorkelling and swimming.

The Bamboo Bike Club offers a unique bike-building course in Hackney Wick, east London. You can learn how to build your own custom frame and enjoy a fun weekend of bike-building. The course is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, who have spent years perfecting their craft.
The course includes a detailed instruction on how to select bamboo for strength and form strong joints. You will also learn how to cut and glue the tubes, assemble the frame, and wrap the joints. With a final polymer coating for waterproofing, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and any other individual touches.
The bamboo bikes are strong and lightweight, and they ride smoothly. They are also very fun to ride, and they are much easier to handle than traditional metal bikes. The price of the course is less than PS500, which makes it accessible to everyone.

Self-help books are popular in America. There is a big industry for self-help books. Many people write self-help books. But not all self-help books are successful. Some books are rejected because they are too derivative or specialized. The writing style is not important for self-help books. Marketability is everything.
Autobiographies are also popular. But not all autobiographies are true. Some writers do not tell the truth. There are many reasons why writers might not tell the truth. Some writers invent stories to make their books more interesting. Other writers do not want to tell the truth because they are ashamed of their actions or thoughts.
Detective stories are also popular. They are a type of allegory. The crime is a symbol of human greed or lust. The solution to the crime represents the reintegration of the personality with society.
Science writing is also popular. Stephen Jay Gould is one of the greatest science essayists. He said that science is a civilisation of its own. Only scientists can make a good job of presenting science. If you do not live in the community and do not understand its rules, you are crippled from the start.

Air-conditioning is used a lot at Cannons Gym, a popular place for workers in the City of London. It is very hot this summer, so the gym has turned on a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, the gym feels like it is in the Arctic. Air-conditioning is a powerful tool that humans use to control the climate. Many buildings could use other methods of cooling instead of air-conditioning. They could use daylight and natural ventilation, and thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and radiate it away at night. These measures would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
Sundials are instruments used to measure time. They were once a vital time-keeping device, but now they are mostly used as garden ornaments. People are starting to use sundials again because they are becoming more interested in the stars and planets.
Paint Your Own China is a painting course that teaches people how to paint china-painting. The course is popular because it is fun and easy to learn. The students are all there to have fun, not to be experts.

The Wrong Country Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a very reasonable price. When Keith and Dawne went to make the booking, the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast, all of them learning Italian. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
When they arrived at the hotel, they were greeted by a woman who introduced herself as Mrs. Franks. She explained that they had been booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. But when they realized that they were in the wrong country, they became alarmed. They tried to explain their situation to the receptionist, but he did not understand. They were frustrated and tired, so they decided to just go with it.
The next day, they woke up and found that they were being offered beds for the duration of their holiday. They were concerned about the mistake, but they eventually accepted the offer. They spent the rest of their holiday enjoying the lakeside air and the beautiful scenery.

Ernest Shackleton was an American executive who was inspired by the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton. Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a rough idea of what he did. America has only just discovered him. Now the Americans are making up for lost time with powerful enthusiasm. They are producing biographies and accounts of Shackleton's voyage, mounting a grand exhibition, and preparing a film based on his life.
Shackleton was a leader and communicator. He had his values in order and was at his best when he and those dependent on him had a great deal to lose. He was adaptable and willing to let go when something was lost and start afresh.
One of the hardest things to do in desperate straits is notating. Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance and patience. He led by example and showed that everything else falls away when you are in charge.

In the forests of Madagascar, there lives a primate called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker. It bores through wood and probes cavities beneath the surface to find insect larvae. The aye-aye uses its incisor teeth to gnaw its way in and its narrow, elongated third finger to probe and scoop.
Scientists have discovered how the aye-aye locates the insects hidden inside the wood. They found that the aye-aye can sense the cavity itself. When searching for food, an aye-aye taps the surface of the wood with its middle finger and brings its exceptionally large ears forward, focusing them at a point in front of its nose. It can probably also hear the rustle of insects, which might move when disturbed by the tapping from above.
The theory that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in the woodpecker-free forests of Madagascar is an attractive one. But there are other birds that also probe for or glean insects from wood. So, the woodpecker niche may not be vacant.

Most people have photographs of their grandparents, but not many know what their lives were like. Diaries and family stories can give us glimpses of the past, but they are often incomplete or forgotten. Hannah Renier has come up with a way to preserve people's lives. She writes other people's autobiographies and produces a book of at least 20,000 words. The book includes illustrations and a chronicle of the ordinary people's lives.
The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realised that a lot of the past that was part of her own life was disappearing. She started writing other people's autobiographies and people have been very grateful for her work.
The books are not expensive, but the time involved in writing them is. Each book involves up to 30 hours of taped interviews. The cost of the book is nearly PS3,000, with extra copies at PS25 each.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology has a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture. The sculptures are replicas of the originals and are housed in a purpose-built gallery. The museum also has a collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks and minerals.
Cambridge Darkroom is a centre for photography with community darkrooms and a gallery. They offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and abilities. Members can use the darkrooms and young photographers can develop their skills with the Young Members scheme.
The Sedgwick Museum of Geology has a collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks and minerals. The museum also has a collection of Britain's oldest intact geological collection.
The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs has a large collection of air photographs. The photographs are of considerable general interest as a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape.
Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre is a centre where you can create wall hangings by rubbing brass plates off tombs of medieval knights and ladies.

From here to paternity, I have been blessed with 35 years of small children. I have loved every minute of it. I had the pleasure of feeding the baby this morning and that for me is what being a father is all about. I'm terribly lucky with my children. We all love the same things: opera, theatre, books, music. It creates a great bond.
I have been a father for many years. I have made some mistakes, but I have always tried to be there for my children. If they need me, I'm here. I'm always on the basis that they ring me.
I also have a lot of other experiences as a father. I have been through a lot of things with my children, including first concerts, sports days, and holidays. I'm sad that I missed some of those things, but I'm glad that I have been able to make up for them.

Marlowe's epic play, Tamburlaine the Great, is a thrilling night of the year. Terry Hands' production combines the glories of Marlowe's play with speed and physicality. Antony Sher is in terrific form in the title role. The play is set in a sunny suburban lawn and explores the devastating effects of illness.
The British theatre lost a talent of great promise when Michael Wall died at the tragically early age of 44. His play, seen at the Manchester Royal Exchange in May, was a powerful, compassionate study of illness.
Billy Roche's latest play explores the decline of the fishing industry. The play is set in Wexford and has a blistering climax.
The play "Murder by Misadventure" is a traditional thriller. It involves a crime-writing partnership intent on killing each other.
Young director Sam Mendes finds the gold in Jonson's great comedy of 17th-century confidence tricksters. The play is set in Edwardian society and has a stylish staging.

Emma and her friends are playing a game called "Surveillance of a Suspicious Bookshop." They find out that one of the customers is her Uncle Jim. He tries to manipulate her affection and alienate her from her friends. When Emma finds her life in danger, things get dark and compelling.
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, join forces to investigate a train accident that happened in 1915. They find out that their relatives were involved in the accident. The novel is complex and rewarding.
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and knows enough to carry on managing the loft and winning prizes. The story is readable and has a sound basic message.
Robert Westall uses the viewpoint of a mature woman for this chilling story of rural prejudice and persecution. The story is gripping and disturbing.
Sam is a teenager who is overweight and overtalkative. He is awed by his cousin, Lisa, who is from the wealthy side of the family. When Lisa's privileged world crumbles, Sam helps her to find some balance. The story is coming-of-age and could be interesting to both boys and girls.

Science flying in the face of gravity. Journalist Tom Mumford joined students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964, a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. The aircraft took off smoothly, but any illusions the young scientists and I had that we were on anything like a scheduled passenger service were quickly dispelled when the pilot put the Boeing into a 45-degree climb which lasted around 20 seconds. After that, the engines cut out and the transition to weightlessness was nearly instantaneous. We floated aimlessly; the idea of going anywhere was itself confusing. Only gravity, by rooting us somewhere, permits us to appreciate the possibility of going somewhere else. After ten seconds of freefall descent, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its nose dive. The return of gravity was less immediate than its loss, but was still sudden enough to ensure that some of the students came down with a bump. After two hours spent swinging between heaven and Earth, that morning's breakfast felt unstable, but the predominant sensation was exhilaration, not nausea.

I planted my stake in New Zealand. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is the New Zealand winter, and I had nine winters on the trot. I like winter. My parents came up with the idea of buying a small plot of land which 'the kids' could look after. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we'd planted the whole 70 acres. The trees are now 20 years old, and in good fettle. The connection between me and that area is still immensely strong.

Six years ago, my husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' and have been looking after orphaned animals ever since. One day, I was surprised to see a cardboard box being canned towards me. It contained three small grey badger cubs. Their coats were like velvet and their eyes looked up at me from their tiny heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. They were born between mid-January and mid-March and usually spend their early life underground. If orphaned, they die of starvation. These cubs were brought in by builders who had bored into the sett while laying drain pipes. They were cold and whimpering. I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and installed them beside the stove for warmth.
The cubs grew and thrived. They were fed every four hours and eventually started to drink from a bottle and move around. After a few weeks, they were eating cereals and other foods. As the weather got warmer, the cubs began to turn nocturnal and would go for walks only at dusk or late at night. We often went through the orchard and the cubs would chase each other's tails.
One day, I spotted odder badgers in our field. They were probably looking for food. We were warned that they would climb into our badger pen and kill the cubs, so we placed sheet metal over the gate to make it as inaccessible as possible.
We built a sett for the badgers and they moved in. Now, I see the cubs less often, but they still rush up to say hello before they go dashing off into the night. This is their territory now, an area that they have come to know well and a home they have readily accepted.

Sir Edmund Halley was a famous astronomer who lived in the 17th century. He is best known for his comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was to chart the variations of the compass. These variations are now known as declination. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley planned a trip to the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination. However, his trip was aborted because of crew insubordination. He returned to the seas a second time and published a chart of declination in 1701. This chart was used by sailors for many years.
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to retrace Halley's voyage. He wants to commemorate Halley's accomplishments and also collect scientific data. The expedition will involve making measurements that Halley made, but with far more precise instruments. The data collected should help to refine the existing mathematical model of Earth's magnetic field.

Peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their magnificent trains to the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day. Darwin argued that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, rather than by special creation. He believed that the fittest individuals are most likely to survive and reproduce. The peacocks tail was at best a waste of space and in practice a severe encumbrance. Darwin felt obliged to invoke what he felt was a separate mechanism of evolution, which he called 'sexual selection'.
The zoologist Marion Petrie and her colleagues are now exploiting the quasi-wild conditions of Whipsnade to try to settle the matter. They have identified two main questions. First, is the premise correct - do peahens really choose the males with the showiest trains? And, secondly, do the peacocks with the showiest trains have some extra, genuinely advantageous quality, as Wallace supposed, or is it really all show, as Darwin felt?
The mature cocks display in groups at a number of sites around Whipsnade, and the hens judge one against the other. Long observation from hides, backed up by photographs, suggests that the hens really do like the showiest males. What seems to count is the number of eye-spots on the train, which is related to its length; the cocks with the most eye-spots do indeed attract the most mates.

The best boat design combines old and new, says Tom Cunliffe. He designed his own boat, 'The Westerman', which is at the Summer Boat Show in London this week. The boat has a lot of new technology, but it also has some traditional features. It's a beautiful boat, and it's a pleasure to sail on.
My own boat is different. It's a small boat that I designed last year. It's not as big as The Westerman, but it's still a good boat. It has everything I need to sail, but it doesn't have any of the new technology that The Westerman has.
The problem with new boats is that they often have too much technology. This can make it difficult for sailors to enjoy the experience of sailing. I like to sail because it's a challenge. I don't want to have to deal with a lot of technology.
My boat is simple and easy to sail. It's also very comfortable. I can sleep comfortably on my boat, and I can cook a good meal. I'm happy that I have my own boat. It's the perfect boat for me.

Health farms and country house hotels offering spa facilities are popular among people who want to relax and recharge. I was asked to write about my experience at five different places.
A. Henlow Grange is a large and historic house that offers a variety of spa treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and massages. The atmosphere is calm and relaxing.
B. Shrubland Hall is a stately home that offers a medical examination and a specific diet for each patient. The food is tasty and nicely presented.
C. Careys Manor is a charming manor farm that offers a variety of spa treatments, including massages, facials, and body treatments. The atmosphere is comfortable and luxurious.
D. Cliveden is a majestic country home that offers a variety of health and beauty treatments, including a well-equipped gym, saunas, and swimming pool. The food is delicious and the atmosphere is relaxed.
E. Springs Hydro is a modern and purpose-built health farm that offers a variety of spa treatments, including aromatherapy massages and carrot cake. The atmosphere is calm and relaxing.

In the past few million years, humans and chimpanzees have not had much time to develop differences. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. What separates humans from animals is a recent development. Our biological history implies that our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to a small number of genes.
Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many differences between humans and animals are not unique. For example, tools are used by humans and wild chimpanzees, and sea otters crack open clams with rocks. As for language, monkeys have a simple one, with separate warning sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle' and 'snake'.
If human art sprang from a unique genetic endowment, it's strange that our ancestors dispensed with it for at least the first 6.9 million of the 7 million years since they diverged from chimps. The earliest art forms may well have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved.
There are some distinctions between human art and animal activities. Human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and it's transmitted by learning rather than by genes. But these distinctions are not absolute. Like human paintings, the ape paintings served no narrow utilitarian functions.

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a vast and dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed it and wrote about his adventure. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be full of them. These days, you no longer find such people in fiction, let alone in real life.
Blackmore's great adventure consisted of leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert. The team included Britons, Americans, Chinese, camels, and handlers. They faced many challenges, including dysentery, extreme heat and cold, thirst, and dehydration. But they managed to find water and complete their journey.
The desert was very harsh, but Blackmore was determined to survive. He felt strong and muscular despite his physical exhaustion. He was able to walk over anything and felt proud of his accomplishment.

Life was getting out of hand. Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and rediscover the joys of manual labour. Everyone loves technology. It makes life easier and leaves us with more time to do other things. But sometimes, gadgets are not worth the expense or the trouble. Are we as dependent on technology as we imagine? Susan has been letting the household technology fall by the wayside as its natural and often short life expires. She is not tied to a noisy, whirring machine, and she can take her time over the garment. There are some gadgets that Susan would not like to be without. But there are others whose loss has brought unexpected delight. She has come to believe that we could not do without it, and if we do resist the notion that our lives would be unmanageable without the appliances of science, we certainly do not want to relinquish them.

The cabinet-maker Charles Hurst makes furniture. He is very busy and has a lot of work. His workshop is full of half-made pieces of furniture and planks of wood. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built up a very nice reputation for himself. His order book is always full for several months in advance.
If you want a decent cupboard or table, bookcase or kitchen units, Hurst is your man. You can find a furniture-maker easily, but finding a cabinet-maker who takes pride in making beautifully crafted furniture is less easy.
Hurst is self-taught and has a huge natural ability. He is also gracious in his praise for others. However, he is also unremittingly critical of those craftsmen who 'are trying to be artists and take a year to make one piece.'

People sleep for a third of their lives. Sleep is important for our health. It helps us to repair damage and restore ourselves to full efficiency. There are three main theories about why we sleep. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our health. It helps us to repair damage and restore ourselves to full efficiency. The second theory says that sleep is for learning. It helps us to process information that we acquire during the day. The third theory says that sleep is for energy. It helps us to recharge our batteries and have an adequate supply of energy for the coming day.

An eccentric person is someone who behaves in a way that is different from the way most people behave. It can be a passion for doing something that is not common, a compulsion to collect things that others don't have, or a tendency to write letters to the press about things that bother you. Eccentricity is the assertion of our individuality. It is the feeling that you are unique and different from everyone else. Most of us have our own quirks and oddities. We all have things that we are passionate about and things that we are good at. But the desire to be accepted and loved is stronger than the desire to stand out in the crowd. If you have a unique hobby or a strong opinion, you will probably find other people who share your interests. You can join a club, hold a meeting, or organize a rally where you can get together and discuss your common enthusiasms or problems.

Natural books have inspired many people, including me. There are four books that I find particularly helpful and inspiring.
The first book is called The Home of Man by Barbara Ward. It is about the explosive growth of the world's cities and the great themes to which she devoted her life. It is a very eloquent and impassioned plea for sustainable human development.
The second book is Signals for Survival by Niko Tinbergen. It explains the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures. It is a must-read for anyone who loves wildlife.
The third book is My Family and Other Animals by Gerald Durrell. It is a story about Durrell's childhood and his love for the natural world. It is a heartwarming and inspiring book.
The fourth book is The Shell Bird Book by James Fisher. It is a comprehensive guide to birds. It has beautiful illustrations and a lot of information about birds. It is a great book for anyone who wants to learn more about birds.

Book reviews play an important role in the success of books. Publishers and authors have different perspectives on reviews. Publishers rely on reviews to attract readers and generate sales. They often prefer reviews that precisely echo their own response to a book. Authors are devastated by no reviews, but they are more concerned about the book's content than the reviews.
Reviews can be helpful for readers to decide whether to buy a book. They can also help to generate sales. However, reviews are not the only factor that influences book sales. Other factors include the book's content, the book's price, and the book's availability.
Overall, book reviews are a valuable tool for publishers and authors. They can help to increase sales and raise awareness of books. However, they are not the only factor that influences book sales.

Making weathervanes is an ancient craft that has been going on for centuries. Today, the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers. 'That way I can produce a unique personalised item,' he explains. 'A lot of my customers are women buying presents for their husbands. They want a distinctive gift that represents the man's business or leisure interests.'
Graham decided to concentrate his efforts on a weathervane business. He had worked as a precision engineer for 15 years when he and his wife, Liz, agreed to swap roles. That was five years ago and he has no regrets about his new direction. 'My previous work didn't have an artistic element to it, whereas this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I really enjoy the design side.'
Graham has perfected over 100 original designs. He works to very fine detail, always seeking approval for the design of the silhouette from the customer before proceeding with the hand-cutting. Graham also keeps plenty of traditional designs in stock, since they prove as popular as the one-offs.

The Horse Whisperer was a popular book that was published last year. It was written by a British screenwriter named Nicholas Evans. The book has earned Evans a lot of money.
The first months of the year were not very good for Evans. His film project, Life and Limb, fell through. He was disappointed and worried about his finances. He decided to write a novel instead of working on the film.
Evans wrote the novel over the spring. He drove across the US and learned about horses and the men who work with them. He also wrote a synopsis of the novel. He sent the synopsis to publishers. Within a week, the novel was sold to two publishers for a record-breaking amount of money.
Evans is grateful for the success of his novel. He is also grateful for the opportunity to write another novel.

Young Bobby Fischer is a chess player who is known for his powerful moves and his ability to win games. He is playing against Boris Spassky, his old adversary. Fischer's victory in the first game was a masterpiece, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is older and out of practice. The game has also changed a lot since then. It is more professional and there is more pressure on the players. The game is also longer and there is more preparation involved. But Fischer still loves to play chess and he is excited to be back in the game.

Fame and fortune are two things that many people dream of, and there are a few young Brits who are making their dreams a reality.
Nick Grosso is a playwright who has written three critically acclaimed plays. He is currently adapting his first play, Peaches, into a screenplay. Although he is gifted, the most extraordinary thing about Nick is that he had never been to or read a play before he wrote Peaches. He left school at 16 and returned a year later to enroll at the Young People's Theatre.
Simon Pegg is a comedian who has written a television comedy series and has just finished a punishing tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has worked hard to hone his craft, even as far back as Bristol. He has performed with the comic am Funny Business, but his relationship with Steve Coogan that has proved the most fruitful.
Ciaran McMenamin is an actor who has gained a lot of recognition for his role in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. He has been using his acting skills to get ahead in his career.
Neil Taylor is a pop singer who has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. He has worked hard to achieve his success, and he is grateful for the opportunity to make his dream come true.
Stephen Richards is a poet and author who has won more prizes than anyone twice his age. He is well known on the poetry circuit, and his first novel, Hidden, will be published in March. He has a passion for writing and has been working hard to achieve his dream.

In this novel, there is a character named Isabel who is an art student. She is concerned about her knobbly knees ruining her chances of finding Mr Right. However, hope springs eternal and she finds Mr Right. The author writes with terrific verve and uses a staccato drama-laden pace.
The novel also tells the story of a local radio station in America. Francis, a young and intelligent child, works for the station. The station beams out a variety of programs, including singers, preachers, and soap-opera heroes.
The novel also includes a story about a second husband gossiping with his wive's first husband. And it tells the story of two sets of best friends who meet in London and are bound together in life and death.
Overall, this novel is a well-written and entertaining read. It is full of interesting characters and events.

International voluntary work, also known as volunteer tourism, can have both positive and negative impacts. While volunteer tourists can contribute to building homes or schools, they often pay a significant fee for the opportunity to be involved in this work. This money could potentially be used to pay for a greater amount of labour than the individual volunteer could ever hope to provide.
Volunteering can also lead to greater international understanding, conflict resolution, and participation in global affairs. However, if volunteering is limited to individuals of means from wealthier areas of the world, it may not benefit people and communities who currently lack access to international voluntary work.
At its worst, international volunteering can be exploitative or self-serving. At its best, it can bring benefits to individual volunteers and the organisations they work for, as well as provide space for an exchange of technical skills, knowledge, and cross-cultural experience.
Volunteer tourism can also be seen as a way to help others. However, it is important to be aware of the potential negative impacts of volunteer tourism, such as bypassing democratic processes and reducing development to individual acts of charity.

The clock radio is a common device used to wake people up in the morning. To choose a good clock radio, you need to consider several factors. The 'dual alarm function' does not allow you to snooze or be driven out of bed. Instead, it allows you to set two different wake-up times. The inclusion of a cassette player is a great feature, allowing you to fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up to a day without news. The quality of the radio is excellent, but the size is a bit big. The clock has a self-power back-up so you don't have to reset it if someone pulls the plug out. However, setting up the clock radio can be a bit tricky. The simplest and cheapest model is the best choice for those who want a straightforward and reliable clock radio.

'Hedgehogs are small mammals that have sharp spines on their bodies. They live in many different places around the world, but they are not native to America or Australia. When they are attacked, hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball, with their spines pointing outwards. This is a good defence mechanism, but it depends on the number of spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs have fewer spines and are more likely to try to run into their attacker. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep for much of the day. They sleep in bushes or in holes in the ground. Hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. In suitable conditions, some hedgehogs will stay awake all year round. '

To excel in any sport is difficult, even for men. But women have to be even tougher. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. Despite the challenges, women are breaking records and achieving their goals.
Here, we talk to just a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
A. Jill is a skier. She says, "It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. You just get on with it. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months of the year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends."
B. Caroline is a cyclist. She says, "I'm well paid as a pro, and cycling has lots of potential in terms of endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly and it worries me that people may think I've got where I'm because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist."
C. Annabel is a rower. She says, "Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools do it. So most don't start till they're 19 or 20 which makes it harder to succeed at an international level."
D. Ffyona is a long-distance walker. She says, "I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record!"
E. Lisa is a saloon car racer. She says, "Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks!"

I was travelling around Europe and Morocco when I met Picasso. He was eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes harbour. I was a student and I was drawing. I had a sketchbook and I asked Picasso if he would sign it. He agreed and he inscribed his name on the paper. He also added a flourish to the drawing. Picasso's art was usually anchored in observed reality. It was a beautiful drawing. I thanked Picasso and asked him if he would sign the drawing. He said that he already had his signature. I was disappointed, but I still felt that I had been lucky to meet Picasso.

Talking shop Ever entered a store and bought more than you intended to buy? Supermarkets know that shoppers like to buy fresh produce. They often put their fruit and veg at the front of the store or display house plants to make the store look more inviting. They also provide an in-store bakery that smells like fresh bread. The layout of the store can also influence how much you spend. Products that are placed in the most visible areas tend to sell better. This is called 'eye-level means 'buy-level'. Supermarkets often spread low-priced staples like bread and sugar around their stores. They also use lighting to make certain foods look more appealing. If you're a shopper, you're more likely to buy fewer items in chainstores than you would in supermarkets. So, the importance of pricing still holds.

Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston are known for their adventures. Chris Bonnington climbed the summit of Everest in 1985. Robin Knox-Johnston was the first to circumnavigate the world single-handedly in 1968. They teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland.
One day, the author was working on a book about adventure and called Robin to ask for an interview. They sailed and climbed together, and the author learned a lot from Robin about sailing and climbing. They also built a strong friendship.
The author found that sailing was very boring and difficult. However, he was impressed by Robin's skills as a leader and his ability to make everyone feel part of the decision-making process. They also had a lot of fun climbing together.
The only time there was a near-crisis in their relationship was on the yacht on the way home. The author felt that Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him that he had jumped to the wrong conclusion.

Apples have been with humans since the beginning of time. They come in many different shapes, sizes, and colors. People have been eating apples for many years. In ancient times, people used apples to make cider and other drinks. They also stored apples for the winter.
In the Middle Ages, there were many different kinds of apples in Britain. Some of the most famous apples from this time include the Old English Pearmain and the Costard. During this time, people also started to experiment with new apple varieties.
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples are grown commercially and come from just a few different varieties. This is a problem because it can make it difficult for people to find the apples that they like.
We need to do something to save the diversity of apples. We can all help by buying a variety of apples and by supporting organizations that are working to preserve apple diversity.
