We specialize in travel to new and unusual destinations, coupled with interesting and original itineraries. Our brochure contains over 100 original adventures in more than 60 countries worldwide. Our trips offer a variety of activities, including hiking, safaris, and exploring remote wilderness areas. We also offer a unique opportunity to meet ethnic or tribal peoples and learn about their cultures.

The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar is one of Britain's top runners. He visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator. It is a beautiful spot, but it is also lonely and isolated.
Richard has trained with Kenyan runners on their home soil. He also competed in his first-ever race in Kenya. The race was held in Nairobi. It was the first-ever international cross-country race to be held on African soil.
Training at high altitude produces more red blood cells, which improves oxygen-carrying capacity. Kenyan runners are also known for their simple diet and relaxed manner of conversation.
The national team training camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya. The camp is basic, but it has everything the athletes need to train. The athletes live in cinder-block dormitories and have three work-outs each day.
By the time Richard left the camp, he was even more appreciative of Kenyan success. He couldn't stop himself pondering upon a rather different explanation for their success.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main reason for the decline is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change.
When you go shopping, you probably buy a few advertised brands. But you don't buy most of the brands you see advertised. Most people buy only a small number of advertised brands.
Advertising is still cost-effective. It is a cheap way to reach a large number of people. But it is wasteful. There is no way to know which people will respond to an advertisement.
If the advertiser knew exactly which people were going to respond, there would be no point in using media at all. The advertiser could communicate with them directly.

Southwell in Nottinghamshire is a place where you can find two amazing things. The first is Southwell Minster, which is a very old cathedral. The second is the 'autonomous house', which is designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat. The house is super-insulated, with krypton-filled triple-glazed windows, which means that you do not hear a sound inside. There is also a lot of draught-proofing in the house. The Vales pay no water bills. And last winter the house used only nine units of electricity a day costing about 70p.

The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted that these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. But it can, and always could. Today, we are used to computer software enabling us to rework our digital images and it is a myth that photography ever had a true age of innocence. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Blacksmiths have been working with iron for many years. They have made weapons, armour, and farming tools. They have also been praised for their artistry. In the past, blacksmiths were very important people. They were like doctors and astrologers. But over time, the number of blacksmiths decreased. This was because heavy industry no longer needed them. However, there has been a recent revival of blacksmithing. This is due to greater interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design.
There are many different types of blacksmithing. Some blacksmiths make gates and balconies. Others make bookends and sculptures. Still others make jewelry and tools. No other metal can give man as much visual pleasure or a greater feeling of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are good.

The day I gave up smoking, I was pleased that everyone would be happy. But one of my colleagues was very angry. She said, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I guess my inability to explain how I had been a smoker for many years and how I had stopped four hours later was a little annoying. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnosis. It took place two months and three weeks ago. I had not planned to stop and I did not really want to. But I did stop. The stop-smoking messages made sense. They helped me to see that smoking was a problem and that I could stop. It was not easy, but it was not that difficult either. I am coming to the view that smoking had a lot to do with boredom. I miss my cigarettes, but I am not smoking.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also the first woman to win a Nobel prize.
Hodgkin's life was full of accomplishments and challenges. She had three children and was married to a historian. She was also devoted to her scientific work.
Scientific inquiry was Hodgkin's passion. She pushed the technique into realms of complexity others deemed unreachable at the time. Her work on penicillin and vitamin B12 was very important. It helped to save many people's lives.

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability to find water. She can hold a forked hazel stick above the ground and detect water. She is very busy these days because there has been a lot of drought. Most of her customers are farmers whose wells have dried up. To find water, Margaret uses a map and a hazel stick. She also checks the land with her hazel stick. If she finds water, she drills a well. The water that she finds is running in fissures of impervious rock. It should give a good clean supply. However, there are some challenges when drilling a well. One challenge is the cost of electricity to run the pump. Another challenge is the risk of farm or other waste getting into the water supply. If Margaret does not find water, she will keep looking until she does.

We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed of swapping lives with someone else for a day? It would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
Amanda, a young mother, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who works as a waitress at a restaurant. Amanda had a busy day taking care of her two daughters. Cindy had a busy day waitressing and taking care of the children.
Rosemary, who runs a dairy farm, swapped lives with Hilary, a teacher. Rosemary had a busy day milking cows and making ice-cream. Hilary had a busy day teaching children and inspecting sheep.
D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to discover that Rosemary had been up for hours. The process of milking cows and making ice-cream is very tiring. I found it quite a lonely day.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He was born in southern Sweden and has a unique talent for playing the trumpet. His records are continually opening up new repertory, not just concertos by long-neglected composers, but new works too.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo and owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father had the idea of giving his only son a trumpet. The success of the gift was instant. The boy never stopped playing. He had a natural talent for playing the trumpet and was taught by Bo Nilsson, a second trumpet-player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra.
Hardenberger has a unique gift of communicating through his music. He is able to make people feel happy and sad, excited and relaxed. He is also able to make people feel connected to themselves and to others.

New In Paperback A is a novel set in the fictional republic of Efica. The book is notable for its humour and the author's unique vision. It also includes a story about a teenager who viciously attacked a young boy. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. The book follows the fortunes of one of the most isolated of the Scottish Orkney islands and its inhabitants over a long and uneventful rural history. The author is skilled at exposing the haunting sadness that hovers beneath the seeming ordinariness of life.

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different professions. Each woman has her own unique job and challenges.
A. The Brain Surgeon
Anne is a brain surgeon. She operates on patients all Monday and Wednesday, as well as some Friday afternoons. She has to work long hours and sometimes worries about what she's going to do the next day.
B. The Senior Designer
Marita is a senior designer. She spends a lot of time managing people and working on projects. She has to deal with deadlines and keep up with a lot of work.
C. The Chauffeur
Linda is a chauffeur. She has to be careful not to get tired and has to deal with rude passengers.
D. The Landscape Gardener
Tracy is a landscape gardener. She spends a lot of time working outdoors and has to deal with the weather.
E. The Civil Engineer
Zena is a civil engineer. She works on building bridges and retaining walls. She has to deal with a lot of paperwork and find solutions to problems.

Six people talk about their typical working day.
A. Credit Card Executive
I wake up early and arrive at the office early to manage all the customer development programmes for our regular credit card users. I have to keep in touch with existing card users, acquire new ones and build relationships with partner companies. I have a lot of meetings and I also deal with a lot of e-mail messages.
B. Record Company Executive
I get to work late and go through a lot of paperwork. I listen to demo tapes and try to be constructive. I sign bands and start on the first album. I oversee budgets and spending and I also go to gigs.
C. Sales Director
I wake up early and drive to work to arrive at 9.30 am. I open the post and check if we're going to see any clients that day. I love taking people round the showrooms and I also do the accounts and tax returns.
D. Air Traffic Controller
I work a set shift pattern and deal with a lot of aircraft movements. I have to be really switched on and I find the work quite stressful.
E. Shop Manager
I get to work early and get the point-of-sale system up and running. I help customers and order books for them. I also deal with publishers' reps and make sure new titles are delivered on time.
F. Financial Analyst
I listen to the news and assess financial risk for multi-national companies operating abroad. I provide three services and travel to Africa about three times a year. I leave work early and have a hard time switching off.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. To be a good leader, you need to inspire, be an agent of change, and develop others. It's not about being tall or intelligent. To convey enthusiasm and encourage it in others, a good leader should be able to speak clearly and with conviction. You also need to be able to set goals and achieve them. To become a leader, you need to recognise your latent talents, develop them, and use them. You can benefit from improving your leadership skills, regardless of your position. To be a successful leader, you need to be able to delegate, motivate, organise, and chastise effectively. You also need to be visible and accessible to those who are important. But remember, you don't have to lead all the time.

The movie "A Abyss Long Before Titanic" is a Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded deep underwater. The movie has impressive production design and special effects, but the dialogue and characterization are not as strong.
The movie "The Thin Red Line" is a war movie about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is a conventional war movie, but it has some interesting moments. The flashback sequence, in which the soldier dreams of his wife, is handled with a harshness which arguably works better than Malick's soft-focus imagery of the woman on the swing.
The movie "On Guard" is a swashbuckler adventure film. It is corny but highly watchable. The film has a consummate villain and an exuberant hero.
The movie "Character" is a dark and vicious parable set in turn-of-the-century Rotterdam. The film has excessive production and costume design, but the storytelling is not as strong as the visuals.
The movie "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" is a digitally re-mastered war epic. The sound editing is impressive, but the storytelling is relentless and cruel.

Steve Martin's book, "Compelling Evidence," is a compelling read. The narrator, a lawyer, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting and the book has a surprising twist at the end.
Sigmundondo, a charismatic troubleshooter, is the protagonist of "Curtains for the Cardinal." The plot is complex and the book is long, but it is still a great read.
Sarah Lacey, a tax inspector, is the detective in "File Under: Deceased." She is a gutsy and versatile detective who is able to solve the case despite facing challenges.
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is a high-quality detective novel. Spenser, a private investigator, assists his friend Hawk in clearing drug dealers out of a deprived estate.
Faye Kellermann's book, "False Prophet," is an entertaining mystery. The author's easy writing style and eye for odd human behaviour make this book a pleasure to read.

I'm 34 years old and I'm nervous about backpacking. I've done it before, but I've been busy with my job and relationship. I decided to quit my job and rent out my flat to go travelling in South East Asia for a year.
There are a lot of reasons why people are backpacking in their thirties. Some people want to get away from their jobs and relationships. Others want to rediscover themselves. And still others want to have a new adventure.
There are also a lot of factors to consider when you're planning a backpacking trip. You have to make arrangements for your accommodation, transportation, and food. You also have to decide where you want to go and what you want to do.
I'm excited about my trip, but I'm also nervous. I'm not sure if I can handle the challenges of backpacking. But I'm determined to give it a go. I'm going to take the next 12 months and enjoy myself.

The home office of Georgina McGuiness had changed a lot since she had taken a long break from journalism. She was able to transform the family home into an efficient workplace. She had everything she needed to work from home, including a computer, a modem, and a telephone-answering facility. She also set up a mini-office in a corner of the kitchen.
The computer has helped McGuiness to be more organized and efficient. It has also made it easier for her to research stories and get information for her articles. However, there are also some challenges associated with working from home, such as isolation and distractions.
McGuiness believes that the future of home workers is bright. She is confident that she will be able to continue to write articles and even publish her own magazine from home.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The museum building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.
The museum has a lot of exhibitions. There are stories about the history of Scotland. There are also stories about the people who lived in Scotland. The museum has a lot of beautiful objects. There are jewels, silver, and paintings.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre. It is a place where children can learn about the history of Scotland. The Discovery Centre has a lot of interactive games and activities.
Overall, the Tartan Museum is a very interesting museum. It is a must-see for anyone who is visiting Scotland.

The end of print may take some time. It's a calming concept. Change can be frightening and challenging, but it also means going from somewhere to somewhere else. Newspapers are facing a decline in sales, but their websites are growing. The decline in print sales is happening in the West, but Asia is making up the difference. Books are also changing. Kindle and similar e-readers are booming, but booksellers found that sales of physical books have only decreased slightly. There are a lot of different trends happening in different countries. In Britain, sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%. And in France, the fall is only 3.1%. These trends reflect a situation that is more complicated than people think. Newspapers have to find a way to attract a paying readership. They are using paywalls and joint packages to do this. However, it is difficult and expensive to maintain both an active website and an active print edition.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. To take a good picture of people, you need to be aware of actions, gestures and expressions.
When photographing people, there are a few things you can do to improve the quality of your pictures. First, avoid straight lines in group shots. Second, help your subject relax and find a comfortable position. Third, make sure that the subject is not overwhelmed by the background. Fourth, ask your subject to look into the lens. Fifth, look for familiar expressions and gestures that go with the subject's personality. Sixth, consider the overall composition of the picture, including the subject's placement and the background. Finally, take your time and experiment to find the best shot.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made the work. Janson has been painting trompe-l'oeil for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
When Janson finishes a painting, she often feels that she has not done it justice. She is also brutally honest about her 'failings' and is frank about her mathematical abilities. Despite her inclination to play down her talent, Janson is constantly busy. She is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas.

In today's workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and the emotions of others. EQ includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social adeptness.
There are many benefits to having high EQ. For example, it can help you to be more successful in your job, build stronger relationships with colleagues, and improve your overall well-being.
More and more businesses are seeing the value of EQ and are incorporating it into their management philosophy. If you want to be successful in today's workplace, you need to develop your EQ skills.

**
The media can earn money from content they don't own. Social media has made it easier to capture newsworthy events. Sometimes, journalists use images from social media as sources of images for fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. There is a debate about whether this is ethical. Research shows that a lot of people film or photograph news events. This means that UGC has a big part to play in the future of the media. To prevent problems, the media needs to make sure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most popular.
Acupuncture points are located along meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become weak or sick.
To treat pain, acupuncturists use fine needles that are inserted into the skin at specific points on the meridians. They may also use warmth from smouldering herbs or pressure at points on the meridians.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to relieve pain during surgery.
If you are considering acupuncture for pain relief, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your condition with your doctor to see if acupuncture is right for you.

P.D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her intricate and brilliant imagination. She exudes an air of quiet authority, but it is soon apparent that she is actually shy. She has written 12 major detective novels that are read avidly by millions worldwide. She is a great fan of the works of close friend Ruth Rendell and enjoys reading detective stories.
James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She also became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science.
Writing detective stories is a way for James to bring order out of disorder. She believes that the solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable.

The pen is more powerful than a psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is a science that can reveal a person's character and health. If you apply for a job in some countries, you will probably be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting will be used to determine your suitability for the job.
Graphology can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. It can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs.
However, most doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the value of graphology. They say that handwriting is a product of education, artistic ability and the type of writing taught - and has no other significance.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments.
In Office A, the team of seven people have created a happy, homely working environment. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and roof panels or switching on electric radiators.
In Office B, the office is comfortable and well-maintained, but it lacks personality. The walls are bare and the environment is impersonal.
In Office C, the office is very busy and has a lot of activity. However, the desks and chairs are not very inspiring.
In Office D, the office is very dusty and uncomfortable. The furniture is old and the space is cluttered.
The survey found that the most important factors for a healthy and happy workforce are fresh air, comfortable chairs, and a positive work environment.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States, where people chew an average of 12 million sticks a day. Gum is made from a natural substance called chicle, which is obtained from the sapodilla tree. In the past, people chewed gum made from the bark of trees or from a resin obtained from the mastic tree. Today, most gum is made synthetically. It contains fewer than ten calories per stick, but it is classified as a food and must therefore conform to the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration. Gum manufacturers say that chewing gum can help reduce tooth decay. They say that 20 minutes of chewing gum can increase your salivary flow.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels that offer a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. The Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small rural village dominated by craftsmen, while the Hermitage Hotel is situated amidst breathtaking scenery on a glacier. Both hotels provide basic facilities, but their unique charm and tranquil atmosphere make them popular among travelers.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another tranquil retreat. Surrounded by a private beach and lush greenery, this hotel offers a serene escape for those seeking a quiet getaway. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia is known for its dramatic setting and colonial style. Its open rooms offer stunning views of the Pitons and the Caribbean Sea.
The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic gem that exudes a charming atmosphere. Its unique architecture and cozy rooms make it a perfect place to relax and unwind. The Chateau d'Etoges in France is a beautiful seventeenth-century chateau that offers a unique blend of history and luxury. The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable option for travelers seeking a peaceful retreat.
The Hotel Splendido in Italy is steeped in history and offers a glimpse into the glamorous world of the past. Its elegant atmosphere and impeccable service make it a sought-after destination for celebrities and discerning travelers alike.

The hotel inspector, Sue Brown, judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was not aware of the guest she was ignoring. Sue was not happy with the service. She said, "Very poor." It was a classic arrival-phase error. Sue has encountered this many times before. However, the hotel is still rated among the top 130 of the 4,000 listed in the hotel guide. There was a problem with the access to the hotel and the room. The room was stuffy and had a large hole in the wall. Sue was tough and she made her opinions known. She suggested that the hotel manager fix the problems and not usher guests into the room so readily. The manager agreed to listen to her suggestions. He was grateful that Sue was not going to recommend that the hotel be stripped of its red stars.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I climbed Mt. Everest with my climbing partner, Dougal Haston. We were in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I recalled other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
I climbed Mt. McKinley with Dougal Hatton. The air pressure in the polar regions is lower than at sea level, which has an impact on the body out of all proportion to its altitude. We packed our bags and finally staggered onto the summit and down the other side, triumphant.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
I climbed Kilimanjaro with Paul Braithwaite. We got lost in the dense jungles of the lower slopes and ran out of water. We spent the third night on a windswept ridge; by now we were both suffering.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
I climbed Aconcagua with my wife, Sharu. We decided to miss out on the glacier and go across the north ridges instead. The wind was strong as we walked the last few metres to the summit.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
I climbed Vinson Massif with a team. We all got to the top within 8 hours, but the visibility was down to just a few metres in the storm.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
I climbed Elbrus with a team. We crossed open slopes and reached the summit.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
I climbed Carstensz Pyramid with a team. We reached the summit by 11 am. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Style Merchants Style is a company that provides information about the latest fashion trends. Jo Foley, Ned Ingham, Sally Quail, Lily Grimson, and Peter Little are some of the designers who work for Style Merchants Style.
Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He says that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks in favour of simpler styles. He has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy.
Sally Quail is a jeweller. She designed her own engagement ring and set up her own business. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.
Lily Grimson designs handbags. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are full of glamour.
Peter Little is a hairdresser. He has been styling hair for over 20 years. He says that most women want real-looking hair and a style they can manage at home.
Penny Pratt is a florist. She has a small shop and provides floral ideas to a number of top restaurants. She has also started her own London Flower School.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is a popular place to stay for business and leisure travelers. The hotel offers a variety of services, including 24-hour room service, laundry service, and valet parking. The hotel also has a team of friendly and helpful staff who are always willing to go the extra mile to make sure that guests are satisfied.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks them and then takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

The Brackham area had a lot of trees that were brought down in a terrible storm in March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had changed the appearance of the town centre. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was not able to notice the change because he was sick. He had been sick with bronchitis and was unable to work. When he finally got well, he realized that the loss of the trees had made a permanent difference to the appearance of his living-room. The house stood in a sizeable garden. The garden had created an impression of privacy. Now, though, the storm had changed his outlook. Previously, the view from the living-room had featured the handsome walnut tree. With the tree gone, the room seemed cruelly bright, its worn furnishings exposed in all their shabbiness.

**
Living in the valley, we had lived there for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers that could exist in the surrounding hills. It was the year when the storms came early, before the calendar even hinted at winter. Until that time, we felt safe and sheltered in our valley below the protecting hills. Soon snow began to fall. It was deep and made the streamside path slippery and dangerous. But on the neighbouring heights the snow was much deeper and stayed for longer. The wind blew fiercely and the trees swayed. We knew that there was reason for us to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient but they did not really trouble us greatly. It was the river that threatened us most. The river flowed wildly and surged over the banks. For three days we prayed that it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our prayers were answered and the waters began to subside. We can now enjoy the huge clouds that hang over the valley and be thrilled by the tremendous power which we know the river possesses.

Film critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. It was his first proper job. Before that, he had done some reviewing for other newspapers and magazines. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a different idea for the team of critics. He thought that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't require specialized knowledge. There would be a weekly lunch at which the team would make their choices from the artistic material that Tom had decided they should cover. It all felt like a dream at that time. It seemed unlikely that a paper could be introduced into a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help Mark personally, and was pretending to employ him. Mark felt lacking in self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground, he didn't know where to look. Tom's original scheme for a team of critics for the arts never took off. It was a good idea, but they didn't get together as planned. So everything was done by phone. Mark chose film as his area of focus. Without Tom's initial push, they would hardly have come up with the present arrangement.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. Teenager with a taste for endurance WANTED: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. Chance to work with potential Olympic champion. Should be extremely keen on distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (addiction to winter training in cold rivers useful) and distance cycling (love of 1OOkm an advantage). Ability to do all three without a rest essential.
The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping. It's great fun, and all worth it in the end.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. 'I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my team-mates as I went round.' Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she came nowhere. 'I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realised then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometres too far. I cried all the way through the running.' But she did not give up and is determined that she never will.

The hobby of collecting is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. Many people enjoy collecting things, and one in three adults indulges in this hobby. If you enter this world, remember one thing: if you do not fall in love with an object, do not collect it.
People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Primitive man collected pebbles, and children still collect stones and seashells. You can also collect flowers, pottery, paintings, or even toys.
If you want to start a collection, you do not have to be rich or powerful. You can start with small items, such as tulip bulbs or china cups. You can also collect items that are important to you, such as family photos or souvenirs from your travels.
It is the way that collections change hands that has always interested me. As small objects become a popular collector's item, they begin to rise in price. The toys of the 1950s are now positively an investment.

My job is to put together temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I have to read up about the subject of the exhibition and talk to important people in the area so that I can establish the main themes and aims of the exhibition. I also have to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition and plan interactive displays, workshops and theatre.
I teach London taxi drivers how to pass their test. I check the accounts and see what new maps and documents need to be produced. I help students work out the most direct route and give them advice on how to take the test.
I live by the coast and work from home as a marine conservationist. I respond to telephone enquiries, produce educational resources and set up training courses. I also work with schools and study centres and run courses for coastal managers and those involved in making decisions about the fate of the seas.
My job is to publish maps and atlases. I have to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that we keep stocks of the books that we publish. I also have to deal with a lot of administration which leaves less time to work on the more interesting tasks such as product development and design.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have done everything very discreetly.
We've been playing cards together for ages. Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia and myself. We call me Milly, though strictly speaking my name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko picked up his nickname at school, Dekko Deacon sounding rather good. We're all about the same age and live quite close to the town where the Malseeds were before they decided to make the change from England to Ireland.
Mrs Malseed is always waiting in the large, low-ceilinged hall that always smells of flowers. She painted flowers on the doors of the hotel instead of putting numbers. In winter, when no one much comes to Glencorn Lodge, she sees to little details like that; her husband sees to redecoration and repairs.
We had a good time at Glencorn Lodge. Nothing had changed. We played cards, and there was a lot of people around. We also went for walks on the beach. The next day, we drove to a different place. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since first we came here, we'd all fallen hopelessly in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.

A chalet girl's work is never done. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She works for a company that provides chalets for skiers. Sarah's job includes making beds, cooking delicious dinners, and cleaning the rooms.
Every day, Sarah gets up early and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and prepares the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible. In the evening, she cooks dinner and prepares the evening tea. Sometimes she will chat with the guests or clean the rooms.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares breakfast for the guests who are leaving. After the guests leave, she cleans the rooms and does the shopping. She then prepares tea for the new guests and gets them settled in.

Miss Rita Cohen, a young girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was small and had a lot of hair. She was interested in learning about the leather industry. Three or four times a year, people would ask Seymour for permission to see his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering questions or giving them a tour.
Rita was small like the children from Marie's class. Marie was tall and had fair hair. They had a lot of things in common. They were both interested in learning and they were both good at remembering things.
Seymour offered to show Rita how to make gloves. He said that the process was primitive and that it had not changed much over the years. He also told her about the history of leather tanning.
Rita was excited to learn about the process of making gloves. She was eager to learn everything she could about the trade. She was also interested in learning about the history of leather tanning.
At the end of the lesson, Seymour offered to make Rita a pair of gloves. He said that he would bring her right through the whole process. He was going to make her a pair of gloves and she was going to watch them being made from start to finish.

Chris Arnot asked four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem.
A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job and gets on well with her boss, but she can't stand flying.
B. David Brown is a golf caddy. He prefers the golf to his accounting job, but there are drawbacks.
C. Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. He loves to cook and he was offered a full-time job as a food writer.
D. Dick Prince is a children's writer. He started writing children's stories about 20 years ago and he loves to write letters to his fans.

In the yard by the lake, there was an old brick building. There was a lot of sawdust around the building. One afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the old building. He jumped off the roof and fell on the sawdust. He was laughing and he invited his friends to jump down. One by one, they jumped down and they were all grinning. Michael was still on the roof, watching them. He was waiting for his friends to jump down. Finally, one of his friends jumped down and Michael followed suit. They lay on the sawdust pile and talked for a while. At last, it was time for dinner. Michael was ashamed and he walked home.

If you are unhappy with your job, you can turn to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then conduct a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. Based on the results of the tests and your own input, the adviser will suggest various careers and the retraining needed.
Last March, Donna Laney lost her job and decided to go to Career Analysts for help. She was advised to take a year off and work in the Far East or to move into something more suited to her skills. Donna decided to use the skills she already had and move into something more suited to her than insurance. She is now working as a Public Relations officer.
If you are feeling stuck in your career, a visit to a careers adviser might be the right thing for you. However, it is important to remember that careers advice doesn't work for everyone. If you are not satisfied with the advice you receive, you should not hesitate to seek additional guidance.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a comfortable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist. To make people feel more relaxed, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He has a lot of relaxation techniques, such as virtual-reality headsets and a pleasant smell in the surgery. He also uses a special instrument that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to do research into dental techniques. He found out that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself. He sees his patient-centred attitude as the start of a gradual movement towards less formality in the conservative British dentistry profession.

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is a popular treat worldwide. People in Britain spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter and Christmas. The cacao plant, which is where chocolate comes from, was first cultivated by the Aztecs, Toltecs and Mayans thousands of years ago. The fruit of the cacao tree contains seeds that can be used to make chocolate. In the past, chocolate was made from solid blocks that had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, a Dutch inventor named CJ van Houten invented chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate. Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week.

Peter Cooke is an artist who makes delicate and unusual objects out of shells. He has been making these objects for the past ten years. He has a miniature mind and uses materials as and when he finds them. He collects dead shells from all over the world.
Cooke's work is beautiful and often greater than its natural parts. He uses a lot of different materials to make his work, including cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid. He has a unique working method and is able to achieve a high level of attention to detail, colour gradations, and symmetry.
Cooke's quest for beautiful shells has taken him to many different places. He has traveled to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines to collect shells. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who write him letters accusing him of stripping the world's beaches.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on magazine covers, she is usually studying for her school exams. One day, the receptionist at the agency told Jane that Kira would be late. Jane was trying to convince herself that all the bad things she had read about models were not true, but the words difficult, vain and unintelligent kept coming into her head. When Kira arrived, she was smiling, relaxed and apologetic. She was not dressed in expensive-looking designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. Kira explained that all models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. She also said that she has to manage her two separate lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her success, but a few unkind people at her school are rude about it. Kira has the looks, ability and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They have a mine on the side of a Welsh mountain that could contain up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a five million dollar vein of gold.
The pair have dedicated their lives to the hunt for gold. They started their search after the father read about pockets of gold worth millions of pounds buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt'. They spent the past ten years getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth, and removing old cars and rubbish. Now they are running short of money and need to convince a backer to put PS50,000 into the project.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into steep decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples, and then three hours to get back up to the surface. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, there is such a sense of wonder.

I was dirty, smelly, and hungry. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more. I was tired of foreign timetables, currencies, and languages. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. The train ticket allowed me to travel all over Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've slept in the corridor of a train. Carrying all your possessions on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel. It encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks and getting rid of books when finished. But this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. You can travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time.

**
There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not there, you may have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, airlines lose luggage, even the best ones. It is impossible to guarantee that your luggage will go on the same flight, particularly when there is a change of aircraft.
The system for baggage handling works like this. Airlines require you to check in at a specific time before your flight. This is to allow enough time for your baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Sometimes, there are problems with the baggage system. These problems can become severe at large transfer airports. If your luggage is lost, you must contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR).

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has a powerful image that lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent a lot of time watching them. He also took pictures of them.
The kingfisher is a popular bird to photograph. It is easy to watch from a hideout. You can see the kingfisher's colours and movement. Charlie James' first hideout was an old blanket which he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favourite spot. The bird came back within minutes and sat only a metre away.

Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson is a conductor who works with a well-established opera company in London. She has conducted several projects with Claudio Abbado.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label.
C. Wasfi Kani started conducting seriously in her late twenties. She likes the long practice period which is part of any opera production.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He has conducted several projects from the piano.
E. Wayne Marshall is a conductor who was noticed by Simon Rattle in 1986. He has conducted several projects in London.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best.
There are rides for all ages at most theme parks. Younger children can enjoy the Crocodile Ride, the Giant Wheel, and the dodgems ride. Older children can enjoy scarier rides, such as Splash Out and the ferris wheel.
The park is well designed and easy to navigate. There are places where you can put your feet up and relax. The landscaping is perfect and the staff are friendly and helpful.
You need a full day to enjoy a theme park. There are a lot of rides to see and enjoy. You can also spend time relaxing and having fun with your family.

Running a business in the countryside is a rewarding experience for women. Five women talk about their experiences setting up businesses in the countryside.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She moved out of London to the country with her children and wanted to work from home. She had worked with computers before she was married, so she set up a business that needed a huge amount of money. But she has been very careful and has managed to make her business successful.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She trained in art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when she married, she moved to the countryside, where there wasn't that sort of work. So she decided to set up her own business and produce a range of greetings cards.
C. Delia Turner's curtain-making business has seen good times and bad. She started her business eight years ago and had to sack her employees due to the decline in the economy. But she is back on track, making the curtains at home herself.
D. Tessa Strickland runs the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside for financial reasons and enjoys being able to work when she wants to.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She started her business ten years ago at home and has expanded it to a large operation.

Meet the Watkins family, a group of talented musicians. The sons, Paul and Huw, are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments.
One day, John, a schoolteacher, decided to make a cello for his son, Paul. He discovered that there was a school of instrument making nearby and took evening classes for several years. After a few tries, John made a beautiful cello that Paul used for many years.
Paul's brother, Huw, is also a musician. He started playing the piano at a young age, but he didn't take to it. However, he did take to the cello and began playing with his dad's group.
The Watkins family is proud of their musical achievements. Paul won a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. Huw is also making his own mark as a pianist and composer.
The Watkins family has a lot of musical talent. They are a joy to listen to and their music brings joy to many people.

The National Trust is an organization that protects the beautiful areas of the British countryside. Gareth Roberts is a warden employed by the Trust to look after the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales.
To be a National Trust Warden, you need to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and has a lot of experience farming. He won the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience.
Gareth's job includes conservation, public entry to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. He also has to make sure jobs get finished and deal with reports and bills.
Despite never being off duty, Gareth enjoys every minute of his work, especially talking to the public. However, he does admit that there are some people he dislikes.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of the England team. She has a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She teaches at a local school and has a training session in the local supermarket car park.
The World Championships are big and there will be a lot of pressure on the team. The first game is against Barbados. The team is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be tough.
Kendra is proud of her team and she is excited about the Championships. She has a strong mental attitude and she leads by example. She also thinks it is important to have a good training program and to be able to concentrate on your movements and your feet.
As captain, Kendra has a lot of responsibility. She has to make sure that the team is prepared for the game and that they are playing their best. She also has to be able to motivate and encourage the team.

If a child has a natural talent for music, it can be difficult to know how to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may not recognize or respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour. Most schools are not able to deal with children who are especially able in music. If a child has a lot of musical ability, they may benefit from the education offered by a specialist music school.
There are five music schools in Britain that offer a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also spend several hours a day practising in properly equipped private rooms.
There are some disadvantages to attending a specialist music school. One disadvantage is the cost. The fees are high, but each school will make every effort to help parents find the necessary fees. Another disadvantage is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school. Finally, it can be stressful to be a musically gifted child. But all specialist schools do keep a close watch on the progress of individual pupils, and offer help and advice if needed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. They left plants that appealed to Susan. She also inherited the gardener, Danny.
Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. She picks them and then takes them up to her studio. She takes one flower out and paints it, which might take a few days. Then, she brings in another flower and builds up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.
Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out. The poppies also come out at the same time. She finds it fascinating to see how the flowers change and grow. She has always been interested in plants. She used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside. Nowadays, the garden owes much to plants that originated in far-off lands.

A chalet girl's work is always done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. She is a 24-year-old from West Sussex who works for a company in Val d'lsere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible.
In the evening, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She does not sleep. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, she clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. She takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of the magazine Marie Claire. She usually wears a uniform at work, but she wore a different outfit for this day. She went to a photo studio, then to press previews, and finally to a fashion shoot. Mandie enjoys her job at the zoo, but she was surprised to see how much work goes into making magazines.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent the day at London Zoo. She wore a polo shirt and trousers that the zoo gave her. She stroked one of the elephants and thought about Mandie packing up clothes. Alice had a great day, but she was tired. She would like to work with elephants in Africa someday.
Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team and was impressed by the chance to be in the fresh air. Karen thought she was strong, but she felt weak compared to the rest of the team. She was more enthusiastic than effective, so she didn't plan to give up her other job.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with the TV programme Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. Charlie felt his job was a waste of time compared to nursing, but he was satisfied with his work.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt different when she put on the uniform and felt self-conscious. Lucy was surprised to see that some of the trainers didn't eat healthily, but she was inspired to join a gym and try to be healthier.

The railway is a special way to travel. Many people have fond memories of their favorite train journeys.
Andrea Thompson, a newsreader, loves the south of France. She often travels there by train. The train takes her past amazing seascapes and beautiful gardens. It's always enchanting, no matter what the weather is like or what time of the year it is.
Raj Patel, an explorer, enjoys train journeys through the desert. He has a favorite journey across the Nile Valley in Sudan. He was disappointed that he couldn't travel by train to the Kruger National Park in South Africa.
Betty Cooper, a novelist, is grateful for one particular train journey. It took her and her husband on their honeymoon to Egypt. It was a special journey because her husband gave her a pink dress.
Martin Brown, a journalist, had a memorable train journey in Africa. He was working on a series of articles and had to cross a desert. The only way to continue their journey was to take the Desert Express.
Arisu Mezuki, an actress, has a passion for steam trains. She made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. The filming took place on an old, disused stretch of the line. It was a special journey because everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform.

If you want to get your story published, there are a few things you need to know. First, you need to research your market and find out about publishers. You also need to practice your writing skills. To become a successful writer, you need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at. You can do this by reading everything relevant you can lay your hands on.
Once you have done your research, you need to start writing. Write as much as you can and keep practicing. Each story you write will be better than the last. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. But don't be discouraged. Just keep writing and eventually you will get published.

On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting for the train in the Baltimore railway station. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples with their luggage and college kids with their bags. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He looked well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He also came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. I understood why he didn't ask me. He probably thought I was unreliable. He swerved off toward the bench at the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. He was talking to a woman reading a book. He said his daughter was flying out for a study year abroad and he had to go home to find his wife. The woman felt sorry for him. I waited to see where he was heading with this. He said he couldn't go himself because his wife was in a wheelchair. I thought that was a poor excuse. Also, it exceeded the amount of bad luck that one family could expect. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. They looked like they were going to be alright.

John Moore, a restaurant owner, has a close relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Everyone has a chance to succeed in life, and John believes that his son Gary was given his chance with cooking. When John heard about an opportunity, he rushed to look at the place. It was perfect for his business. Coming into this business made John recall his childhood and the importance of family life. He dedicated himself to running the restaurant and his wife took care of the children and finances. They lived over the restaurant and always emphasized having meals together.
Gary was a lively child and had a natural talent for cooking. He started helping out in the kitchen at a young age and was very disciplined. He was up even before his dad in the morning and always had loads of money at school. Gary was not very academic, but he shone so much in the kitchen. He was as good as any of the men working there and sometimes he was even left in charge.
John is proud of his son's success and believes that if you work hard, you can achieve anything. He has always tried to tell Gary that if you want something, you have to work for it. Gary went to catering college and was successful from the beginning. He is now helping other people out and John is very happy with his accomplishments.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true.
The flat was upstairs and there was a cheerful-looking girl coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.'
Jo went on climbing and met a punk named Pauline. She had seen some of them on O'Connell Street, but hadn't met one close up to talk to.
They were just about to have a mug of tea and Jo introduced herself. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I rang.'

**
Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent, sensitive to human emotions, and allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
There are many different kinds of dolphins. Some dolphins live far out in the open sea, while others live near to coasts. The bottlenose dolphin is one of the most common types of dolphin. Bottlenoses are social creatures that live in groups. They are often seen near to European coasts.
One of the biggest threats to dolphins is pollution. Pollutants can build up in the bodies of dolphins and can cause a number of health problems. Another threat to dolphins is overfishing. If fish are removed from an area, dolphins may not be able to find enough food to survive. Human disturbance is also a major threat to dolphins. Noise pollution from ships and other sources can disturb dolphins and make it difficult for them to communicate.
Dolphins are an important part of the ecosystem. They help to regulate the food chain and they are a source of joy for people all over the world. It is important to protect dolphins so that they can continue to live and thrive.

Getting fit is important for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to stay healthy and balanced. There are many reasons why you should exercise. It can improve your muscle tone, strength, posture and flexibility. It can also help you to prevent injuries, relieve stress and improve your mood. If you're not sure what type of exercise is best for you, you should talk to your doctor. To improve your posture, you need to stretch regularly. Stretching can help you to improve your flexibility, ease of movement and prevent muscle tears and injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you'll definitely see the benefits.

In their natural habitat, Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman, film-makers, are often away from home for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their current habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are currently trailing a shy animal, the jackal. Film-makers have been travelling the world to point cameras at exotic wildlife since the beginning of television.
The rest of their daily diet consists of pre-packed meals that are heated and dished out by whoever is at hand. It can be a rough existence, but the appeal of being alone in such remote areas is that they can get close enough to the animals to become part of their lives.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of the England team. She has a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She teaches at a local school and trains in the local supermarket car park.
The World Championships are big and there will be a lot of pressure on the team. The first game is against Barbados. The team is ranked fourth in the world, but the Championships will be tough.
Kendra is a strong leader. She has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She also thinks it's important to have a good training program and to be able to concentrate on your movements and your feet.
As captain, Kendra has a lot of responsibility. She has to make sure that the team is ready for the game and that they are playing their best. She also has to be able to motivate and encourage the team.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. It's like letting go of a ping-pong ball in the bath.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching. She loves teaching, but she does it so she can get on with her research.
The only time Rachel has been frightened is when she first went down with the Americans. There was an explosion and she thought, "I'm going to die." But she was still alive.
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the underwater volcanoes, there is such a sense of wonder.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce was studying to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job. The Head Teacher said that if someone doesn't take the time to present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?
It is important to have a professional image and to communicate clearly. If you want to do well in an interview, you should dress professionally, make good eye contact, and speak clearly and concisely. You should also be prepared to answer questions and show that you are interested in the company.

The Farmer Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent but now runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He supplies meat through mail order and is glad he's no longer stuck in the office.
The Painter Ron Able white was a manager in advertising but now makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He was helped by a career counsellor and has been lucky in that his friendships have survived the distance.
The Haymaker Katherine Goodison set up her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. She left her job as a lawyer because she wanted to have a better work-life balance and was happier in her new job.
The Masseur Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He got qualifications in massage and is now happy and in control of his destiny.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports.
Darius is a runner. He has always been sporty and played a bit of everything, but he was best at football and athletics. He competed for his country in the youth team and got a medal. It was a big moment for him, but it didn't result in much media attention.
Gabriel is a surfer. He is very serious about his sport and often the best waves are at dawn. He has to cut out late-night parties altogether to be successful. But he does love having a lie-in and he usually has to give that up too.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He is very traditional and always celebrates a win in great style. Sometimes the reporters seem more concerned about where you go out celebrating and what you get up to there than about where you came in the race.
Tomas is a tennis player. He loves being spotted by fans, but it also has some downsides. His last girlfriend didn't like it if he got too much attention from female fans.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, they want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Parents sometimes have a hard time deciding what to buy. They feel guilty if they say no to their children's demands. And they feel bad if they give in to their children's demands. Sometimes, parents are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is a popular place to stay for business and leisure travelers. The hotel offers a variety of services, including 24-hour room service, laundry service, and valet parking. The hotel also has a team of friendly and helpful staff who are always willing to go the extra mile to make sure that guests are satisfied.

Where I get my energy, Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it.
A. Jeanette Kupfermann is a journalist and author. She says, "I get tremendous energy from doing something that's a challenge and learning new things. Dance is also very energising."
B. Linda Kelsey is an editor. She says, "If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low even though you may be feeling tired. Exercise also gives me energy."
C. Annie Nightingale is a disc jockey. She says, "I get my energy from being positive and being sociable. I love taking photographs and writing words for imaginary songs."
D. Floella Benjamin is an author and children's TV presenter. She says, "My energy comes from things I do and enjoy. I love working with kids and playing with them."
E. Deborah Moggach is an author and playwright. She says, "I love making a garden out of complete wasteland and knowing that somebody wants to read what I'm writing."
F. Katherine Monblot is a therapist. She says, "You must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. Doing things you don't want to do wears you out."

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bones. Now, people use skates made from metal. Skating is a popular sport that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. If you are new to skating, you should start by learning the basic figures. Once you have mastered the basic figures, you can move on to more advanced moves. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and strength. It also improves your heart and lung health. Combined with other activities, such as swimming or jogging, skating can provide a great overall health and fitness programme.

If there's one thing that can make you cry, it's seeing a child win a medal. Julia Gregson asked three young stars, and their mothers, to share their stories.
A. Annika Reeder won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics. It's hard to train for the Olympics, but Annika is very determined.
B. Annika's mother said, "To perform at the level Annika does is so demanding of time and energy you have to want to do it yourself."
C. Sarah Stokes made her first show-jumping appearance at ten. She has won the British National Championship. Show-jumping is a lot of fun, and Sarah is very passionate about it.
D. Sarah's mother said, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse, age 1, that was it, her passion."
